title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement serkor1@duck.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Cryptocurrency Market Data in R
text: supported intervals varies exchanges, market. example supported intervals Binance futures market spot market intervals, can extracted setting futures = FALSE, availableIntervals()-function invisibly returns character vector, can used , example, lapply extract cryptocurrency different intervals. source controls exchange. example returned using Kucoin exchange,
code: ## available intervals ## from Binance futures market cryptoQuotes::availableIntervals(   source = 'binance',   futures = TRUE ) ## ℹ Available Intervals at binance (futures) ## ✔ 1s, 1m, 3m, 5m, 15m, 30m, 1h, 2h, 4h, 6h, 8h, 12h, 1d, 3d, 1w, 1M ## available intervals ## from Binance spot market cryptoQuotes::availableIntervals(   source = 'binance',   futures = FALSE ) ## ℹ Available Intervals at binance (spot) ## ✔ 1s, 1m, 3m, 5m, 15m, 30m, 1h, 2h, 4h, 6h, 8h, 12h, 1d, 3d, 1w, 1M ## available intervals ## from kucoin spot market ## and its return value print(   cryptoQuotes::availableIntervals(     source = 'kucoin',     futures = FALSE   ) ) ##  [1] "1m"  "3m"  "5m"  "15m" "30m" "1h"  "2h"  "4h"  "6h"  "8h"  "12h" "1d"  ## [13] "1w"

title: Cryptocurrency Market Data in R
text: currently supported exchanges can retrived using availableExchanges()-function, also invisibly returns character-vector,
code: ## supported exchanges ## and its return value exchanges <- cryptoQuotes::availableExchanges() ## ℹ Available exchanges ## ✔ binance, kucoin, kraken, bitmart ## print its value print(   exchanges ) ## [1] "binance" "kucoin"  "kraken"  "bitmart"

title: Cryptocurrency Market Data in R
text: listed, active, cryptocurrencies supported exchanges available extraction using getQuotes()-function. cryptocurrency tickers varies across exchanges, within markets exchanges. Supported tickers specific exchanges markets can retrieved using availableTickers()-function, NOTE: availableTickers() can’t run CRAN, Github, doesn’t allow API calls. availableTickers()-function returns character-vector, sorted alphabetically.
code: ## available tickers ## on Binance futures ## market cryptoQuotes::availableTickers(   source  = 'binance',   futures = TRUE  )

title: Cryptocurrency Market Data in R
text: get cryptocurrency market data R, getQuotes()-function used. example get Dogecoin 1 minute intervals using Binance exchange, DOGEUSDT class xts zoo, following structure seen , USDT denominated Dogecoin structure arguments can modified according application, example getting ATOM 15 minutes intervals perpetual futures market using Binance exchange , USDT denominated ATOM structure Note: getQuotes() can’t run CRAN, Github, doesn’t allow API calls. datasets examples can found library.
code: ## DOGEUSDT on the ## 1m chart from the ## spot market DOGEUSDT <- cryptoQuotes::getQuote(   ticker   = 'DOGEUSDT',   source   = 'binance',   interval = '1m',   futures  = FALSE,   from     = '2022-01-14',   to       = '2022-01-15' ) ## ATOMUSDT on the ## 15m chart from the ## futures market ATOMUSDT <- cryptoQuotes::getQuote(   ticker   = 'ATOMUSDT',   source   = 'binance',   interval = '15m',   futures  = TRUE,   from     = '2023-01-01',   to       = '2023-01-02' )

title: Interactive Cryptocurrency Charts in R
text: charting cryptocurrency, get ATOMUSDT pair Binance 15 minute intervals,
code: ## ATOMUSDT on the ## 15m chart from the ## futures market ATOMUSDT <- cryptoQuotes::getQuote(   ticker   = 'ATOMUSDT',   source   = 'binance',   interval = '15m',   futures  = TRUE,   from     = '2023-01-01',   to       = '2023-01-02' )

title: Interactive Cryptocurrency Charts in R
text: basic ohlc chart can charted passing ATOMUSDT-pair ohlc()-function wrap chart()
code: ## simple bar-chart ## without indicators chart(   chart = ohlc(     ATOMUSDT   ) )

title: Interactive Cryptocurrency Charts in R
text: japanese candlestick chart can charted passing ATOMUSDT-pair kline()-function wrap chart()
code: ## simple kline chart ## without indicators chart(   chart = kline(     ATOMUSDT   ) )

title: Interactive Cryptocurrency Charts in R
text: charts supports various indicators RSI Bollinger Bands. indicators starts addIndicator, can used pipe operator magrittr.

title: Interactive Cryptocurrency Charts in R
text: example using addRSI() addBBands() indicators,
code: ## simple kline chart ## without indicators chart(   chart = kline(ATOMUSDT) %>%      addRSI() %>%      addBBands() )

title: Interactive Cryptocurrency Charts in R
text: example using addMACD() addVolume() indicators,
code: ## simple kline chart ## without indicators chart(   chart = kline(ATOMUSDT) %>%     addMACD() %>%      addVolume() )

title: Interactive Cryptocurrency Charts in R
text: Various events financial markets , undoubtedly, impact prices. traders relying technical analysis one important event short simple moving average (SMA), crosses long SMA. can use TTR::SMA() calculate SMA, Based cross indicator, ATOMUSDT pair can now subset, processed accordingly. Finally, crosses can plotted using chart() addEvents() functions, like ,
code: ## Calculate moving averages ## SMA(7) and SMA(10) ATOMUSDT$short_SMA <- TTR::SMA(   x = ATOMUSDT$Close,   n = 7, )  ATOMUSDT$long_SMA <- TTR::SMA(   x = ATOMUSDT$Close,   n = 21, )  ## Determine the cross ## from below ATOMUSDT$cross <- as.numeric(   lag(ATOMUSDT$short_SMA) < ATOMUSDT$long_SMA &     ATOMUSDT$short_SMA > ATOMUSDT$long_SMA  ) ## create event data ## and store it as a data.rfrae event_data <- subset(   ATOMUSDT,   cross == 1 )  # 1.1) Extract the index # from the event data index <- zoo::index(   event_data )  # 1.2) Convert the coredata # into a data.frame event_data <- as.data.frame(   zoo::coredata(event_data) )  # 1.3) Add the index into the data.frame # case insensitive event_data$index <- index   # 1.4) add events to the data. # here we use Buys and Sells. event_data$event <- 'Bull Cross' event_data$color <- 'darkgray' ## add the events ## the chart, along ## with Moving averages ## and the Bollinger Bands ## in a candlestick chart chart(   chart = kline(quote = ATOMUSDT)  %>%      addBBands()                    %>%     addMA(FUN = TTR::SMA, n = 7)   %>%     addMA(FUN = TTR::SMA, n = 21)  %>%      addEvents(event = event_data) )

what: Changing the time zone of XTS and Zoo objects
title: Changing the time zone of XTS and Zoo objects
text: example changing time zone Sys.timezone(), Time zone comparsion
code: # 1) store ATOMUSDT to  # ATOMUSDT_local to avoid # overwriting the data ATOMUSDT_local <- ATOMUSDT  # 2) changing the time zone attributes(zoo::index(ATOMUSDT_local))$tzone <- Sys.timezone()

what: Converting xts and zoo to tibble
title: Converting XTS and ZOO objects
text: Converting tibble requires steps achieve data structure xts,
code: # 1) load pipe library(magrittr)  # 2) convert to tibble # using as_tibble tbl <- tibble::as_tibble(   x = cbind(     Index = zoo::index(ATOMUSDT),     zoo::coredata(ATOMUSDT)   ) ) %>% dplyr::mutate(   Index = lubridate::as_datetime(     Index   ) )  # 3) head data head(tbl, 3) ## # A tibble: 3 × 6 ##   Index                Open  High   Low Close  Volume ##   <dttm>              <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> ## 1 2023-01-01 00:00:00  9.35  9.41  9.34  9.38 148613. ## 2 2023-01-01 00:15:00  9.38  9.43  9.37  9.41 104498. ## 3 2023-01-01 00:30:00  9.41  9.41  9.38  9.38  77118.

what: Converting xts and zoo to data.table
title: Converting XTS and ZOO objects
text: Converting data.table straightforward .data.table() handles everything hood,
code: # 1) convert to data.table # using as.data.table DT <- data.table::as.data.table(   ATOMUSDT )   # 2) set column name to upper colnames(DT)[1] <- 'Index'  # 3) head data head(DT, 3) ##                  Index  Open  High   Low Close    Volume ## 1: 2023-01-01 00:00:00 9.351 9.407 9.343 9.382 148613.44 ## 2: 2023-01-01 00:15:00 9.382 9.425 9.366 9.411 104498.21 ## 3: 2023-01-01 00:30:00 9.411 9.415 9.381 9.382  77117.57

title: Converting XTS and ZOO objects
text: important date.time converted different timezone process, without explicitly coding ,
code: # 1) store date.time objects time_objects <- list(   tbl = tbl$Index,   DT  = DT$Index )  # 2) check if they are all equal all(   sapply(     time_objects,     function(x) {              setequal(         x = x,         y = zoo::index(ATOMUSDT)         )            }   ) ) ## [1] TRUE

title: Converting XTS and ZOO objects
text: goes without saying R-functions wouldn’t tamper order data conversion without warning documentation, nonetheless sake argument, check OHLCV values,
code: # 1) store price objects # Open price here open_price <- list(   tbl = tbl$Open,   DT  = DT$Open )  # 2) check if they are all equal all(   sapply(     open_price,     function(x) {              setequal(         x = x,         y = ATOMUSDT$Open         )            }   ) ) ## [1] TRUE

title: Converting XTS and ZOO objects
text: Even though numerical operations xts-objects lightning fast (12% faster data.table), comes cost; doesn’t support factors characters. Converting xts-object simple trivial process, simplifies grouped operations verbose manner.

title: Cryptocurrency Market Data with Quantmod and TTR
text: ATOMUSDT can passed directly quantmod::chartSeries()-function , desired, relevant technical indicators. Pass quantmod::addBBands() quantmod::addMACD TA-argument, add Bollinger Bands Moving Average Convergence Divergence (MACD) indicators,
code: ## chart the spotAtom ## with a candlestick ## chart with Bollinger Bands ## and MACD indicators quantmod::chartSeries(   x = ATOMUSDT,   theme = quantmod::chartTheme("white"),   TA = c(     # Add Bollinger Bands     quantmod::addBBands(),          # Add MACD     quantmod::addMACD()   ) )

title: Cryptocurrency Market Data with Quantmod and TTR
text: NOTE: quantmod supports daily interals , therefore, functions like allReturns() needs modified.
code: # 1) find peaks # using a small threshold; peak_idx  <- min(   quantmod::findPeaks(   ATOMUSDT$Close,   thresh = 0.022   ) )  # 2) add to main to main # chart quantmod::addLines(   h = ATOMUSDT[peak_idx]$Close,   overlay = TRUE,   col     = 'steelblue1'   )

title: Cryptocurrency Market Data with Quantmod and TTR
text: Artificial Intelligence applications, like price prediction, numeric value indicators needed, indicators TTR can calculated added returned data cryptoQuotes::getQuote()-function. TTR::BBands() one indicators traders use buy sell signals, can added following way, resulting indicator can fit using, example, lm()-function determine distance affects next closing price. NOTE: case werent awar:, financial advise. merely simple demonstration available applications.
code: # 1) calculate # Bollinger Bands indicator <- TTR::BBands(   quantmod::HLC(ATOMUSDT) )  # 2) add to the  # cryptocurrency quote ATOMUSDT <- cbind(   ATOMUSDT,    indicator )  # 3) calculate # the distance of the # closing Price and upper band ATOMUSDT$distance <- (ATOMUSDT$up - ATOMUSDT$Close)^2 # 1) fit a simple # model using the distance # to the upper band and # lagged closing price # as predictors summary(   lm(     ATOMUSDT$Close ~ xts::lag.xts(ATOMUSDT$Close) + xts::lag.xts(ATOMUSDT$distance)   ) ) #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = ATOMUSDT$Close ~ xts::lag.xts(ATOMUSDT$Close) +  #>     xts::lag.xts(ATOMUSDT$distance)) #>  #> Residuals: #>        Min         1Q     Median         3Q        Max  #> -0.0230962 -0.0094336 -0.0004082  0.0085242  0.0293977  #>  #> Coefficients: #>                                 Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)     #> (Intercept)                      0.62168    0.43153   1.441    0.154     #> xts::lag.xts(ATOMUSDT$Close)     0.93390    0.04586  20.366   <2e-16 *** #> xts::lag.xts(ATOMUSDT$distance)  1.07858    1.13709   0.949    0.346     #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1 #>  #> Residual standard error: 0.0127 on 74 degrees of freedom #>   (20 observations deleted due to missingness) #> Multiple R-squared:  0.875,  Adjusted R-squared:  0.8716  #> F-statistic: 258.9 on 2 and 74 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

title: cryptoQuotes: Cryptocurrency Market Data in R
text: high-level API-client gives access cryptocurrency market data, without rely low-level coding using httr2 curl. currently listed actively traded major cryptocurrencies available download. Note: library uses xts zoo hood therefore follows syntax base R, related libraries. vignette explore case study showcase capabilities library; price action Dogecoin affected minutes Elon Musk tweeted, Tweet Elon Musk - timezone CET.

title: cryptoQuotes: Cryptocurrency Market Data in R
text: Elon Musk tweeted (Well, now X’ed) Dogecoin January 14, 06.18 (UTC) - Dogecoin rallied. determine fast markets reacted tweets, get market data Dogecoin 1 minute intervals day tweeeted using getQuotes(), returns object class xts zoo 500 rows. get closer look price action around tweet hour, can subset data using window()-function, leaves 61 rows, corresponding minute minute price action. can calculate price rallying using 19th row, corresponding minute tweet. Dogecoin closed 0.2055, rallying 8.5%.
code: ## DOGEUSDT the day ## of the tweet on the ## 1m chart DOGEUSDT <- cryptoQuotes::getQuote(   ticker   = 'DOGEUSDT',   interval = '1m',   source   = 'binance',   futures  = FALSE,   from     = '2022-01-14',   to       = '2022-01-15' ) ## extract the hour ## of the tweet DOGEUSDT <- window(   x     = DOGEUSDT,   start = ('2022-01-14 06:00:00'),   end   = ('2022-01-14 07:00:00') )

title: cryptoQuotes: Cryptocurrency Market Data in R
text: can illustrate candlestick charts using chart()- kline()-function,
code: ## chart the ## price action ## using klines cryptoQuotes::chart(   chart = cryptoQuotes::kline(     quote = DOGEUSDT   ) %>% cryptoQuotes::addVolume(),   slider = FALSE )

previous_headings: Cryptocurrency Market Analysis in R > Charting price action with candlesticks
what: Charting price action with event lines
title: cryptoQuotes: Cryptocurrency Market Data in R
text: create , presumably, better visual overview can add event lines using addEvents()-function, takes data.frame kind argument, event data, can passed chart,
code: ## 1) create event data.frame ## by subsetting the data event_data <- as.data.frame(   zoo::coredata(     DOGEUSDT[19]   ) )  ## 1.1) add the index  ## to the event_data event_data$index <- zoo::index(   DOGEUSDT[19] )  # 1.2) add event label # to the data event_data$event <- 'Elon Musk Tweets'  # 1.3) add color to the # event label event_data$color <- 'steelblue' ## 1) create event data.frame ## by subsetting the data event_data <- as.data.frame(   zoo::coredata(     DOGEUSDT[19]   ) )  ## 1.1) add the index  ## to the event_data event_data$index <- zoo::index(   DOGEUSDT[19] )  # 1.2) add event label # to the data event_data$event <- 'Elon Musk Tweets'  # 1.3) add color to the # event label event_data$color <- 'steelblue'  ## 1) chart the ## price action ## using klines cryptoQuotes::chart(   chart = cryptoQuotes::kline(     quote = DOGEUSDT   )%>% addEvents(     event = event_data   ) %>% cryptoQuotes::addVolume(),   slider = FALSE )

title: Authors and Citation
text: Serkan Korkmaz. Maintainer, author, contributor, copyright holder. Jonas Cuzulan Hirani. Contributor.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Korkmaz S (2024). cryptoQuotes: Streamlined Access OHLC-v Market Data Sentiment Indicators. R package version 1.2.1, https://github.com/serkor1/cryptoQuotes, https://serkor1.github.io/cryptoQuotes/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {cryptoQuotes: A Streamlined Access to OHLC-v Market Data and Sentiment Indicators},   author = {Serkan Korkmaz},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 1.2.1, https://github.com/serkor1/cryptoQuotes},   url = {https://serkor1.github.io/cryptoQuotes/}, }

title: A Streamlined Access to OHLC-v Market Data and Sentiment Indicators
text: high-level API-client get current, historical, cryptocurrency OHLCV market data R, without using web-crawlers API keys. API-client uses httr2, xts zoo hood compatible quantmod TTR.

title: A Streamlined Access to OHLC-v Market Data and Sentiment Indicators

title: A Streamlined Access to OHLC-v Market Data and Sentiment Indicators

title: Chart the long-short ratios — addLSRatio
code: # Example on loading # long-short ratio # for the last days # on the 15 minute candle # wrapped in try to avoid # failure on Github  # 1) long-short ratio # on BTCUSDT pair BTC_LSR <- try(   expr = cryptoQuotes::getLSRatio(     ticker = 'BTCUSDT',     interval = '15m',     from = Sys.Date() - 1,     to   = Sys.Date()   ),   silent = TRUE )  # 2) BTCSDT in same period # as the long-short ratio; BTCUSDT <- try(   cryptoQuotes::getQuote(     ticker = 'BTCUSDT',     futures = TRUE,     interval = '15m',     from = Sys.Date() - 1,     to   = Sys.Date()   ) ) #> Error in cryptoQuotes::getQuote(ticker = "BTCUSDT", futures = TRUE, interval = "15m",  :  #>   Service unavailable from a restricted location according to 'b. Eligibility' in https://www.binance.com/en/terms. Please contact customer service if you believe you received this message in error.  if (!inherits(x = BTC_LSR, what = 'try-error') & !inherits(x = BTCUSDT, what = "try-error")) {    # 3) head the data   # and display contents   head(     BTC_LSR   )    # 4) plot BTCUSDT-pair   # with long-short ratio   cryptoQuotes::chart(     chart = cryptoQuotes::kline(       BTCUSDT     ) %>% cryptoQuotes::addLSRatio(       LSR = BTC_LSR     )   )  }  # end of scrtipt;

what: calibrate the time window of a list of xts objects — calibrateWindow
title: calibrate the time window of a list of xts objects — calibrateWindow
text: function high-level wrapper .call lapply modifies xts object stored list().

title: calibrate the time window of a list of xts objects — calibrateWindow
code: calibrateWindow(list, FUN, ...)

title: calibrate the time window of a list of xts objects — calibrateWindow
text: list list xts objects. FUN function applied element list ... optional arguments passed FUN.

title: calibrate the time window of a list of xts objects — calibrateWindow
text: Returns xts object.

title: calibrate the time window of a list of xts objects — calibrateWindow
code: # script: scr_FUN # date: 2023-12-27 # author: Serkan Korkmaz, serkor1@duck.com # objective: Demonstrate the use of the convinience # funtions # script start;  # by default the Fear and Greed Index # is given daily. So to align these values # with, say, weekly candles it has to be aggregated # # In this example the built-in data are used  # 1) check index of BTCUSDT and # the Fear and Greed Index setequal(   zoo::index(BTCUSDT),   zoo::index(FGIndex) ) #> [1] FALSE  # 2) to align the indices, # we use the convincience functions # by splitting the FGI by the BTC index. FGIndex <- splitWindow(   xts = FGIndex,   by  = zoo::index(BTCUSDT),    # Remove upper bounds of the   # index to avoid overlap between   # the dates.   #   # This ensures that the FGI is split   # according to start of each weekly   # BTC candle   bounds = 'upper' )  # 3) as splitWindow returns a list # it needs to passed into calibrateWindow # to ensure comparability FGIndex <- calibrateWindow(   list = FGIndex,    # As each element in the list can include   # more than one row, each element needs to be aggregated   # or summarised.   #   # using xts::first gives the first element   # of each list, along with its values   FUN  = xts::first )   # 3) check if candles aligns # accordingly setequal(   zoo::index(BTCUSDT),   zoo::index(FGIndex) ) #> [1] TRUE   # As the dates are now aligned # and the Fear and Greed Index being summarised by # the first value, the Fear and Greed Index is the opening # Fear and Greed Index value, at each candle.  # script end;

code: # Example on loading # long-short ratio # for the last days # on the 15 minute candle # wrapped in try to avoid # failure on Github  # 1) long-short ratio # on BTCUSDT pair BTC_LSR <- try(   expr = cryptoQuotes::getLSRatio(     ticker = 'BTCUSDT',     interval = '15m',     from = Sys.Date() - 1,     to   = Sys.Date()   ),   silent = TRUE )  # 2) BTCSDT in same period # as the long-short ratio; BTCUSDT <- try(   cryptoQuotes::getQuote(     ticker = 'BTCUSDT',     futures = TRUE,     interval = '15m',     from = Sys.Date() - 1,     to   = Sys.Date()   ) ) #> Error in cryptoQuotes::getQuote(ticker = "BTCUSDT", futures = TRUE, interval = "15m",  :  #>   Service unavailable from a restricted location according to 'b. Eligibility' in https://www.binance.com/en/terms. Please contact customer service if you believe you received this message in error.  if (!inherits(x = BTC_LSR, what = 'try-error') & !inherits(x = BTCUSDT, what = "try-error")) {    # 3) head the data   # and display contents   head(     BTC_LSR   )    # 4) plot BTCUSDT-pair   # with long-short ratio   cryptoQuotes::chart(     chart = cryptoQuotes::kline(       BTCUSDT     ) %>% cryptoQuotes::addLSRatio(       LSR = BTC_LSR     )   )  }  # end of scrtipt;

code: # script: scr_FUN # date: 2023-12-27 # author: Serkan Korkmaz, serkor1@duck.com # objective: Demonstrate the use of the convinience # funtions # script start;  # by default the Fear and Greed Index # is given daily. So to align these values # with, say, weekly candles it has to be aggregated # # In this example the built-in data are used  # 1) check index of BTCUSDT and # the Fear and Greed Index setequal(   zoo::index(BTCUSDT),   zoo::index(FGIndex) ) #> [1] FALSE  # 2) to align the indices, # we use the convincience functions # by splitting the FGI by the BTC index. FGIndex <- splitWindow(   xts = FGIndex,   by  = zoo::index(BTCUSDT),    # Remove upper bounds of the   # index to avoid overlap between   # the dates.   #   # This ensures that the FGI is split   # according to start of each weekly   # BTC candle   bounds = 'upper' )  # 3) as splitWindow returns a list # it needs to passed into calibrateWindow # to ensure comparability FGIndex <- calibrateWindow(   list = FGIndex,    # As each element in the list can include   # more than one row, each element needs to be aggregated   # or summarised.   #   # using xts::first gives the first element   # of each list, along with its values   FUN  = xts::first )   # 3) check if candles aligns # accordingly setequal(   zoo::index(BTCUSDT),   zoo::index(FGIndex) ) #> [1] TRUE   # As the dates are now aligned # and the Fear and Greed Index being summarised by # the first value, the Fear and Greed Index is the opening # Fear and Greed Index value, at each candle.  # script end;

title: split xts object iteratively in lists of desired intervals — splitWindow
code: # script: scr_FUN # date: 2023-12-27 # author: Serkan Korkmaz, serkor1@duck.com # objective: Demonstrate the use of the convinience # funtions # script start;  # by default the Fear and Greed Index # is given daily. So to align these values # with, say, weekly candles it has to be aggregated # # In this example the built-in data are used  # 1) check index of BTCUSDT and # the Fear and Greed Index setequal(   zoo::index(BTCUSDT),   zoo::index(FGIndex) ) #> [1] FALSE  # 2) to align the indices, # we use the convincience functions # by splitting the FGI by the BTC index. FGIndex <- splitWindow(   xts = FGIndex,   by  = zoo::index(BTCUSDT),    # Remove upper bounds of the   # index to avoid overlap between   # the dates.   #   # This ensures that the FGI is split   # according to start of each weekly   # BTC candle   bounds = 'upper' )  # 3) as splitWindow returns a list # it needs to passed into calibrateWindow # to ensure comparability FGIndex <- calibrateWindow(   list = FGIndex,    # As each element in the list can include   # more than one row, each element needs to be aggregated   # or summarised.   #   # using xts::first gives the first element   # of each list, along with its values   FUN  = xts::first )   # 3) check if candles aligns # accordingly setequal(   zoo::index(BTCUSDT),   zoo::index(FGIndex) ) #> [1] TRUE   # As the dates are now aligned # and the Fear and Greed Index being summarised by # the first value, the Fear and Greed Index is the opening # Fear and Greed Index value, at each candle.  # script end;

title: cryptoQuotes 1.2.1
text: Added DOGECOIN data. data extracted 1m chart, around Elon Musks Tweet. Added usecase Vignette Dogecoin Elon Musk showcase functionality library.

title: cryptoQuotes 1.2.1
text: Corrected misspelled ticker Vignette returned Quotes now UTC, . Fixed error `Bitmart API weekly candles throw error.

title: cryptoQuotes 1.2.0
text: arguments now flexible, supports passing Sys.Date() Sys.time() directly get-functions. getQuote() now returns 100 pips preceding specified date, = NULL. returns 100 pips, Sys.Date(), specified date. getQuote()-function can now used follows;
code: ## Specifying from ## date only; ## ## Returns 10 pips getQuote(  ticker   = 'BTCUSDT',  interval = '1d'  from     = as.character(Sys.Date() - 10)  ) ## Specifying to ## date only; ## ## Returns 100 pips getQuote(  ticker   = 'BTCUSDT',  interval = '1d'  to     = as.character(Sys.Date())  )

title: cryptoQuotes 1.2.0
text: Four new functions added, getFGIndex() returns daily Fear Greed Index. addFGIndex() adds Fear Greed Index subplot price charts. getLSRatio() returns long-short ratio varying granularity. Contributor credited. addLSRatio() whidh adds long-short ratio subplot price charts.

title: cryptoQuotes 1.2.0
text: Three new convinience functions added applicable situations, removeBound() splitWindow() calibrateWindow()

title: cryptoQuotes 1.1.0
text: getQuote() now returns 100 pips NULL

title: cryptoQuotes 1.1.0
text: code rewritten compatible httr2, package used httr version 1.0.0.

title: cryptoQuotes 1.1.0
text: next release, three exchanges supported.

title: cryptoQuotes 1.1.0
text: returned quotes local timezone, unintentional feature fixed bugfix.

title: cryptoQuotes 1.0.0
text: CRAN release: 2023-12-13 Initial CRAN submission.
